data.description: With Repustate's natural language toolkit, you can extract key adjectives from data all over the world. Find out which words people are using to describe a particular brand, person or idea.  You must specify at least one of 'url' or 'text' otherwise you will receive an error for providing insufficient arguments.
data.name: Adjectives
cloud
data.description: By default, the response is a list of unique adjectives found. Specifying cloud=1 will return a frequency count of adjectives.

data.name: lang
data.description: The two letter code of the language you're analyzing. The default is English (en); you do not need to specify anything if you're just using English text.

data.name: text
data.description: A block of text. You must use HTTP POST if you're analyzing a block of text.
data.value: This is a big block of new text

data.name: url
data.description: Any valid, URL-encoded URL. Use HTTP POST.
Similar to language detection, but works on many pieces of text all at once. Structured similarly to the bulk sentiment call.
data.name: Bulk language detection
text
data.description: One or more blocks of text. Each argument starting with 'text' will be scored. To help you reconcile scores with blocks of text, Repustate requires that you append some sort of ID to the POST argument. For example, if you had 50 blocks of text, you could enumerate them from 1 to 50 as text1, text2, ..., text50.

Sometimes sentiment alone isn't enough - you want to know which aspects of a particular subject carry sentiment. For example, if you're a hotel, you might be interested in knowing people's opinions on your staff, as well as your amenities and the food offerings.  This API call automically categorizes text according to industry-specific categories. Below you'll find imformation on which industry verticals are supported as well as the categories for each:  hotel (food, price, location, accommodations, amenities, staff), airline (price, staff, in-flight, loyalty), restaurant (price, food, staff, location, atmosphere, events), telecom (price, service, products)

response.name: Categorizations Model

data.name: Categorizations
lang
data.description: The default is 'en' (English). Currently, only English is supported.

data.name: niche
data.description: The group of categories you're interested in using. Options are one of: hotel, airline, telco, retail, restaurant.

data.name: text
data.description: The text you'd like to analyze. You must supply either text or a URL.
data.value: I loved the rooms, but the coffee could have been better

data.name: url
data.description: The URL of the web page you'd like to analyze. You must supply either a URL or a text block.

Often you might be interested in the individual portions of a document's sentiment, rather than the overall sentiment. Chunking is the process of breaking up a document into its more interesting parts and evaluating the sentiment on it. This API call chunks and returns the sentiment for each chunk.  Note that one of text or url must be included, but not both. If both are included, the text value will be used.

response.name: Chunking with sentiment Model

data.name: Chunking with sentiment
lang
data.description: Can be one of the following 'en', 'de', 'fr', 'es'. English ('en') is the default and does not need to be specified.

data.name: text
data.description: One of URL or text must be specified.
data.value: The food was great, but the service was terrible.

data.name: url
data.description: Any valid URL. If the URL specified is a URL-shortened one (e.g. bit.ly), Repustate will follow the redirects properly until the final page is found.

This API call will extract out the most important part of a web page, removing all tags and any common header or footer content. For those familiar with Readability.js, this API call replicates Readability's functionality. You can also pass in a URL to a PDF and obtain just the text from this PDF.  If the article has a main image, the URL to this image will also be returned.

data.name: Clean HTML

data.description: If you feel our sentiment engine is incorrect, you can issue a correction using this API call. This correction will only affect your data and cannot be influenced by others. In other words, if another Repustate user submits a correction stating that "I love hockey" is negative, that will only affect their scoring going forward, not anybody else's.
data.name: Correction
language
data.description: The language of the text you're analyzing.

data.name: score
data.description: The score you think the text should have. Submit -1 for negative or 1 for positive.

data.name: text
data.description: The snippet of text which you're correcting. For best results, only submit the text that needs to be corrected, and not the surrounding text. For example, in the sentence "The hotel's beds were too soft", if you want this to be negative, then submit "beds were too soft" (or maybe even "too soft") as being negative, and not the "The hotel" part of the sentence. This will allow our engine to learn much faster.
Returns any mention of a date in english in form of YYYY-MM-DD. For example, "I'm going to school next week" would have result in "next week" being converted into a date string.

response.name: Data extraction Model

data.name: Data extraction
relative_date
data.description: The date strings are converted relative to a specific date. For example, "day after tomorrow" would be one day after the relative date. By default, the relative date is the current date at the time of the API call. The format of this parameter should be YYYY-MM-DD

data.name: text
data.description: The text that contains one or more date phrases
data.value: I can't wait to go to school tomorrow

data.name: text
data.description: Either a URL or a block of text must be provided. Only used with POST.

data.name: url
data.description: Either a URL or a block of text must be provided. Only used with GET.

Given a piece of text (or a URL to a website), this API call will determine the language of the text in question. The response will contain a two letter code representing the language identified. Possible languages are english (en), french (fr), german (de), spanish (es), dutch (nl) and italian (it).  If a language cannot be accurately detected, an empty string will be returned as the language code.
data.name: Language detection
freq
data.description: The minimum frequency of occurrence that should be returned. If for example you put freq=2, then no n-gram that occurs fewer than two times will appear in your result set. This is useful because most n-grams appear once, but the n-grams that appear repeatedly might be of some importance.

data.name: lang
data.description: The two letter code of the language you're analyzing. The default is English (en); you do not need to specify anything if you're just using English text.

data.name: max
data.description: Up to what length of n-grams that should be generated. The default is 5.

data.name: min
data.description: The minimum length of n-grams that should be generated. The default is 1.

data.name: stopwords
data.description: Include this argument with a value of 1 if you want to omit any stopwords from being included in the n-grams that are generated. The default is 0 i.e. to include stopwords.

data.name: text
data.description: Any block of text. You must HTTP POST when calling with a block of text

data.name: url
data.description: Any valid URL. If the URL specified is a URL-shortened one (e.g. bit.ly), Repustate will follow the redirects properly until the final page is found. You must HTTP GET when calling with a URL.

This API call generates all n-grams within a block of text (or URL) and returns the frequency of their occurrence. For more information about n-grams, check out the Wikipedia entry. You can specify up to what length 'n' you want generated, but anything higher than 5 probably won't return anything useful.  Optional arguments include the ability to filter on a minimum frequency of occurrence as well as a minimum number of n-gram terms (e.g. only show bi-grams or more and skip all unigrams).  Please note that if you are using HTTP GET, any optional arguments need to be URL-encoded. If you are using HTTP POST, any optional arguments should be part of your POST'ed data.

response.name: N-grams Model

data.name: N-grams

data.description: With Repustate's natural language toolkit, you can extract nouns, or people, places and things, from data all over the world. Find the topics that are of importance to your customers with this API call.
data.name: Nouns
cloud
data.description: By default, the response is a list of unique nouns found. Specifying cloud=1 will return a frequency count of nouns.

data.name: lang
data.description: For now, only English is supported for noun extraction.

data.name: text
data.description: A block of text. You must use HTTP POST if you're analyzing a block of text

data.name: url
data.description: Any valid, encoded URL. Use HTTP POST.

Repustate allows you to programmatically create PowerPoint slides with a simple API call. This API call can be really useful for automating reports that need to be generated regularly. You can supply a title for each slide and an image. The image must be base64 encoded. Currently, all slides can contain only a title and an image, and the slides are all on a simple white background. We intend to add the ability to make the slides more dynamic as well as suppling a custom template to use.
data.name: PowerPoint Slides
author
data.description: The author of the slide show

data.name: slide_N_image
data.description: For each slide, you should have an image. Enumerate your slides starting from 1. So you would have an argument called slide_1_image, slide_2_image etc. Image data should be base 64 encoded.

data.name: slide_N_notes
data.description: The text that is passed here gets positioned right under the image. It can serve as a caption to briefly explain the slide in question.

data.name: slide_N_title
data.description: Each slide should have a title. Enumerate your slides starting from 1. So you would have an argument called slide_1_title, slide_2_title etc.

data.name: title
data.description: The title of the report.

data.name: apikey
data.description: https://www.repustate.com/docs/#signup-modal

Repustate's sentiment analysis allows you to determine the sentiment (how people "feel" about a particular topic) from any data source you have access to. Like most of Repustate's API calls, you have a choice of how to specify your arguments. You can supply one of a block of text, a single URL, or a list of URLs.  Note that one of text or url must be included, but not both. If both are included, the text value will be used.

response.name: Sentiment Model
response.body:
{
  "status": "OK",
  "text": "Close
      
        Are you sure you want to block this user?
      
      
        Cancel
        Block",
  "score": -0.3257
}

data.name: Sentiment
lang
data.description: The two letter code of the language you want to analyze the sentiment in. The default is English (en); you do not need to specify anything if you're just scoring English text.

data.name: text
data.description: A block of text

data.name: url
data.description: Any valid url

If you plan on analyzing a large number of text documents (i.e you already have the text and you're not relying on Repustate to grab the content via a URL) then we suggest utilizing our bulk API. With this API call, you can POST up to 500 pieces of text a time when using English and 100 pieces of text at a time for other languages and Repustate will return an XML or JSON list with a score for each block of text.  All languages can be analyzed in bulk, EXCEPT for Arabic. Only one piece of Arabic text will be analyzed per request.
data.name: Sentiment (bulk)
chunk
data.description: If provided (it can be any value, the key "chunk" just has to be appear in the POST somewhere), each result will also have a list of chunks that were extracted from the text.

data.name: lang
data.description: The two letter code of the language you want to analyze the sentiment in. The default is English (en); you do not need to specify anything if you're just scoring English text.

data.name: text
data.description: One or more blocks of text. Each argument starting with 'text' will be scored. To help you reconcile scores with blocks of text, Repustate requires that you append some sort of ID to the POST argument. For example, if you had 50 blocks of text, you could enumerate them from 1 to 50 as text1, text2, ..., text50.
With Repustate's natural language toolkit, you can extract key verbs, or action words, from data all over the world. Find the words that connote an intent to act on a certain product or trend.
data.name: Verbs
cloud
data.description: By default, the response is a list of unique adjectives found. Specifying cloud=1 will return a frequency count of adjectives.

data.name: lang
data.description: The two letter code of the language you're analyzing. The default is English (en); you do not need to specify anything if you're just using English text.

data.name: text
data.description: A block of text. You must use HTTP POST if you're analyzing a block of text.

data.name: url
data.description: Any valid, URL-encoded URL. Use HTTP POST.

description: Repustate's sentiment analysis and text analytics API allows you to extract key words and phrases and determine social media sentiment in one of many languages. These languages include English, Arabic, German, French and Spanish. Monitor social media as well using our API and retrieve your data all with simple API calls.
name: v1
